Definition: the resistance of a bobbin on the spindle and washer, as it is pulled round by the yarn when it is being spun.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the preparation of wool previous to spinning, but after combinfj or cardinsr.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a pulley, or wheel, which is driven (though it may itself drive others), and which, if increased in size, causes those which follow it to work at a decreased speed.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a pulley, or wheel, which drives others (though it may itself be driven), and which, if increased in size, causes those which follow it to work at an increased speed.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the wool derived from waste woollen materials which have been woven, or otherwise mixed with cotton or linen.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the steel bars with upright pins set in them, which are carried by means of a pair of screws from the back rollers of a gill box to the front rollers, and then fall down to a lower pair of screws, and are carried back again.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a roller on a carding machine which acts as a brush to raise the wool out of the swift.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the property which enables a number of fibres of wool to interlock and join together, so that they form a compact whole, and each fibre cannot be separated.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the waste from finishing machines in cloth mills, whicli is used again to cheapen yarn and make it bulky.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a horizontal steel bar with two vertical arms, each with an eye or twizzle at their lower extremities, which is placed on the spindle, and round one arm of which the yarn is wound as it passes on to the bobbin. owing to its rotatory speed being greater than that of the bobbin, it puts twist into the yarn.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the twist, or curl, which is given to the extremities of the flyer, forming a sort of ring for the yam to pass through, sometimes called the twizzle.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a fixed number which can be used to shorten calculations for finding the draft and twist of yarn, and which is obtained by condensing all the fixed quantities in any such process of calculation, and extracting from them their result.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a machine for drawing out and levelling wool, either before or after combing. its essential features are a pair of back and a pair of front rollers, with a set of fallers travelling between them by means of screws.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a skein of thread of a fixed length, 560 yards for worsted ; 840 yards for cotton
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the name given to the wool of one-year-old sheep which have not been previously clipped.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a solid, glazed, and horny kind of hair which grows on badly-bred sheep, rarely more than two inches long, which cannot be twisted into the thread in spinning, and will not take the same colour when dyed as the rest of the wool.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the parts into which a hank or skein is divided when it is being reeled.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: flyer is leading the bobbin when the former revolves faster than the latter. in cone drawing, either can lead the other, but in all other drawings the flyer must lead.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the tying separately of each lea or rap. the band with which this is done is called "lease band."
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the first rollers of a carding machine which draw or lick-in the wool.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the plate which travels up and down the spindles of a drawing box or spinning frame, and on which the bobbins rest, and are thus lifted up and down.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the glossy or shiny appearance which alpaca, mohair, and some english wools, such as lincoln and yorkshire, possess, and which causes materials made of them to look bright
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the same as felting; also, the process by which the felting is carried on.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the hair or wool of the angora goat.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a sort of spinning frame, on which all woollen yarn is spun. another form of it is also used for cotton and worsted.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the worked-up waste from hard-spun or felted cloth, which is used again for low woollen yams.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the portion of the lister or nip comb which is formed by two plates closing together and drawing the wool which is between them through the fallers.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the point where a pair of rollers touch each other, and where, consequently, they hold or nip the wool.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the short wool which is separated from the long by a combing machine.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the travelling of the bobbin up and down the spindle in the process of being filled, so that it may be equally full all over.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a little cup with a slit in it, set in a spinning frame for the thread to run down, and to avoid friction.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the distance between the back and front rollers in a drawing machine or spinning frame.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the process of drawing next before spinning.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the steel bars in a gill box on which the fallers travel.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the name usually given to the first and second cards in the woollen trade.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the fine teeth or points which project from the surfaces of fibres of wool, and which interlock with each other in the process of felting.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the worked-up waste of soft woollen or worsted goods which have not been milled, such as stockings, merinos, and, also, opened-out spinning waste.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the process of dipping a warp into a thin paste composed of flour, starch, or other similar material, in order to give it strength and bind together all loose hairs.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a long ribbon of wool drawn out by a gill box and run into a can. it has no twist in it, and clings together by the nature of the wool.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the equivalent of sliver, but with twist in it, and therefore in the form of a slack-twisted rope. it is made by a flyer winding it round a bobbin.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a lump of hard spinning waste, caused by the yarn curling round the top of the flyer instead of being wound on to the bobbin.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: an upright steel rod, on which the bobbin revolves, and at the top of which the flyer is fastened.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a wooden bobbin, consisting of a barrel and one end with a flange on it, the other end being merely the size of the barrel, to enable the yarn to be drawn off it when lying horizontal.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a lock of wool formed naturally on the sheep's back by a number of fibres clinging together.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: small rollers which run on the top of the swifts of a carding machine, and carry the wool from the workers back to the swift.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a fixed iron or steel pin or rod, on which a wheel revolves.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the largest roller of a carding machine. it carries the wool round to the workers from the strippers, and thence to the dofier.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a name for the ordinary spinning frame on which english worsted yarn is spun.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a ball of combed wool from which the noil has been separated.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a small hook of finely tempered steel, which runs round on the ring of a ring spinning frame, being pulled by the yarn, which is put through it.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a thin place in a piece of yarn, caused by uneven drawing or too much draft in the spinning.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: another name for the flyer-eye.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a small round piece of cloth, with a hole in the centre of it, which is placed on the spindle, and upon which the bobbin runs.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the name given to the wool of sheep of one year old and upwards which have previously been clipped.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the small pulley fastened on to the spindle, on which the band runs which drives the spindle.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the wheel by altering which the amount of draft in a machine is changed.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a wheel which has its circumference covered with teeth.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the wheel by altering which the amount of twist in slubbing or yarn is changed.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a wheel with a thread like that of a screw cut round its circumference.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: the grease which is found in the wool of sheep, and which comes from perspii-ation.
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades

Definition: a  light-weight  lining  material  with  cotton  warp  and spun-silk  filling.  plain  weave,  white  or  plain  colors,  and  only  one grade.  used  for  linings  and  underwear.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  trade  name  of  a  certain  manufacturer  for  his  cellulose- acetate-rayon  materials.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: strong  linen  or  mercerized  cotton  ma terial  with  plain  weave,  made  to  exact  specifications  for  the  wings of  airplanes.  after  the  world  war  the  surplus  was  sold  in  retail stores  for  civilian  purposes.  used  for  shirts,  house  dresses,  childrens garments,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth,  lustrous,  wiry  fabric.  originally  made  with cotton  warp  and  filling  of  pure  alpaca.  now  made  with  cotton  warp and  filling  of  mohair  or  any  lustrous  wool.  used  for  linings,  dresses, and  mens  summer  coats  and  suits.  different  grades  and  weights called  angora,  brilliantine,  sicilian,  mohair,  palm  beach  cloth,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: angora  or  mohair  fiber  used  particularly  in braids,  automobile  tops,  and  pile  fabrics  for  blankets,  upholstery, artificial  furs,  etc.  see  alpaca.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  manufactured  fiber  made  in  imitation  of natural,  or  worm,  silk.  artificial-silk  materials  closely  resemble  those of  silk  and  are  used  for  the  same  purposes.  artificial  silk  is  often combined  with  other  fibers  for  all  kinds  of  woven  and  knitted  fabrics. called  at  first  fiber  silk,  vegetable  silk,  wood  silk,  glos,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  fireproof,  undyed  material  woven  or  pressed  from asbestos,  a  mineral  fiber.  used  for  acid  filters,  fireproof  stage  cur tains,  gloves,  and  other  garments  or  articles  to  be  used  around  fire  or great  heat.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  pile  fabric  made  in  imitation  of  the  real  astrakhan fur  and  used  for  the  same  purpose.  the  curly,  lustrous  pile  is  usually of  mohair.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  heavy  canvas  or  duck,  usually  with  wide,  bright stripes.  used  for  awnings,  hammocks,  etc.  see  canvas  and  duck.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: carpeting  with  long,  soft  pile  (on one  side),  originally  hand  tufted.  first  made  in  axminster,  england, on  hand  looms.  now  machine  woven.  compare  with  wilton.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  name  formerly  stood  for  fine,  strong  knitted undergarments  made  of  egyptian  cotton.  now  applied  to  certain kinds  of  unbleached  knitted  underwear.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  novelty  satin  with  warp  of  artificial  silk  and filling  of  cotton.  has  brilliant  luster  but  is  stiff  and  rather  coarse. used  for  sports  wear,  trimmings,  and  decorative  fabrics.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  thick,  soft,  light-weight  cotton  fabric,  heavily napped  on  both  sides.  colored  figures  and  background  usually reversible  on  face  and  back  of  cloth.  used  for  bathrobes,  infants blankets,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (ba'teks).  fabrics,  either  silk  or  cotton,  that  have  been colored  by  the  batik  process  of  printing,  originated  by  the  javanese.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (batest'),  from  jean  baptiste.  a  soft,  fine  cotton  fabric, either  white  or  in  delicate  tints.  better  grades  highly  mercerized. used  for  baby  clothes  and  fine  lingerie
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  rather  coarse  cotton  material  in  white  or  plain colors,  somewhat  resembling  linen  crash.  used  for  dresses  and  chil drens  suits.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  strong,  closely  woven,  twilled  cotton  material  usu ally  found  in  blue  and  white  or  brown  and  white  stripes.  yarn  dyed. used  for  feather  beds,  mattresses,  pillows,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (from  bengal).  a  heavily  corded  silk  material  in  white or  plain  colors.  used  for  dresses,  coats,  suits,  etc.  not  always  in  style.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  white  linen  or  cotton  material,  the  design  of  which  is a  small  diamond  figure  with  dot  in  center  resembling  a  birds  eye. used  for  towels,  and  for  diapers  and  sanitary  napkins.  also  called diaper  cloth.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  plain  lace  material  of  hexagonal  mesh.  coarser  and heavier  weights  used  for  curtains ;  finer  and  lighter  weights  for  lin ings  and  trimmings.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  soft,  warm,  light-weight  pile  fabric  used  for  womens and  childrens  coats.  when  it  is  in  vogue  there  are  many  similar fabrics  bearing  different  names.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  fine,  soft,  double-width  wool  material  with  a  smooth nap  on  the  face.  better  grades  very  lustrous.  used  for  dresses,  suits, and  coats.  cotton  broadcloth  used  for  shirts,  dresses,  pajamas,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: silks  with  a  conspicuous  woven  figure  made  by  the jacquard  loom.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: carpeting  with  a  plain  back  and  looped pile  on  the  face.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  coarse,  heavy,  and  very  stiff  cotton  or  linen  material. sometimes  made  of  two  fabrics  glued  together. used  for  the  stiffen ing  in  womens  hats,  mens  coats,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  coarse,  rough  material  made  of  jute.  cheaper  grades  used for  gunny  sacks.  better  grades  dyed  or  printed  and  used  for  draperies.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  firm,  bleached  linen  material  made  with  rather coarse  yarns.  originally  used  for  coats  and  aprons  of  men  in  meat shops.  replaced  now  by  cotton  for  utilitarian  purposes.  used  for table  linens,  doilies,  runners,  etc. calico  (from  calicut ,  name  of  a  city  in  india).  a  low-grade, printed  cotton  material,  sometimes  called  print.  used  for  inexpen sive  dresses,  aprons,  shirts,  etc.  now  largely  replaced  by  percale. cambric  (from  cambrai,  name  of  a  city  in  france).  a  fine,  thin, polished  cotton  material  found  in  various  weights,  qualities,  and finishes.  used  for  baby  clothes,  lingerie,  and  linings.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  soft,  napped  coat  material,  usually  tan-colored. originally  made  of  natural-colored  camels  hair. now  often  made  of a  good  quality  of  wool  and  dyed  to  color.  used  for  coats,  capes, wraps,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  soft,  warm  wool  material  with  loose,  glossy  fibers on  the  face.  used  for  dresses. canton  crepe  (from  canton,  name  of  a  city  in  china).  heavier than  crepe  de  chine  but  similar  in  appearance.  see  crepe  de  chine.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  firm  and  rather  heavy  cotton  material  made  of soft  yarns  in  the  serge  weave  with  a  long,  heavy  nap  on  the  face. used  for  silence  cloths,  mens  work  gloves,  warm  underwear,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth,  rather  stiff  fabric  made  of  ramie  fiber and  having  a  glassy  luster.  made  in  the  orient.  also  called  grass cloth,  grass  linen,  chinese  linen,  china  grass  cloth,  and  ramie.  used for  lunch  cloths  and  doilies,  and  for  decorative  household  purposes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  general  name  for  a  class  of  heavy,  plain-woven  material made  of  either  cotton  or  linen.  used  for  tents,  sails,  awnings,  interlin ings,  tarpaulins,  etc.  some  kinds  of  canvas  are  used  for  art  purposes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: silk  material  made  for  holding  the  charges  for  big guns.  after  the  world  war  much  cartridge  silk  was  released  and used  for  civilian  purposes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  fine,  soft,  twilled  wool  material  almost  never  found now.  originally  made  of  fiber  from  the  cashmere  goat.  the  name cashmere  is  now  applied  to  soft  wool  hosiery  containing  some  cotton.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  trade  name  of  a  certain  firm  for  its  rayon  products. celanese  was  the  first  fabric  produced  by  the  cellulose-acetate  process
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  hollow  rayon  filament.  used  for  knitted  goods  and  hosiery.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  trade  name  of  a  certain  firm  for  its  rayon  products made  by  the  cellulose-acetate  process. challie  or  challis  (shal'i).  a  fine,  soft,  plain-woven  wool  material, usually  printed.  not  always  in  vogue.  used  for  blouses  and  womens and  childrens  dresses.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (sham'bra).  a  fine  cotton  material,  usually  made  with a  colored  warp  and  white  filling.  resembles  gingham  in  weight,  struc ture,  and  finish.  used  for  mens  shirts,  womens  dresses  and  aprons, and  childrens  clothes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (sham  wa  set').  a  fine,  firmly  knitted  cotton  material with  a  nap  so  short  and  soft  as  closely  to  imitate  chamois  skin.  used for  fabric  gloves.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  cheap,  loosely  woven  cotton  material  formerly used  for  holding  cheeses  in  the  process  of  making.  different  qualities of  cheesecloth  from  which  the  natural  wax  of  the  cotton  fiber  has been  removed  are  used  for  absorbent  purposes  in  surgery.  called hospital  gauze,  surgeons  gauze,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (shar'muz'),  "a  charmer.  a  soft,  beautiful  satin material.  comes  in  different  grades,  sometimes  with  wool  back.  used for  gowns.  cotton  charmeuse  is  made  in  imitation  of  the  silk.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (shenel'),  "a  caterpillar.  a  thick,  fluffy,  light-weight pile  material,  alike  on  face  and  back.  usually  of  wool  but  may  be of  silk  or  cotton.  loosely  woven  of  a  yam  made  especially  for  the purpose.  found  in  plain  colors  or  elaborate  woven  designs.  used  for draperies  and  hangings.  not  always  in  vogue.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  somewhat  harsh  and  hairy  material  originally  hand woven  from  the  strong,  coarse  wool  of  the  cheviot  sheep.  now  made commercially  of  any  coarse  wool.  also  found  in  cotton  and  cotton mixtures.  different  weights  used  for  dresses,  suits,  coats,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (chif'on;  french,  she  fon),  "a  rag.  a  thin,  sheer,  almost transparent  silk  material  formerly  used  for  veilings,  trimmings,  and millinery  purposes.  used  for  dresses  and  dainty  underwear.  not  al ways  in  vogue.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  heavy  wool  double  cloth  with  a  curly  pile  on  the face.  named  from  chinchilla  fur,  which  it  originally  resembled. used  for  coatings
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  firmly  woven,  smooth,  printed  cotton  material.  design usually  made  of  small,  closely  distributed  floral  figures.  used  for curtains,  trimmings  for  hangings,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: heavily  glazed,  printed  in  large  floral  designs, and  used  for  bedspreads,  dustcovers  on  furniture,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (cor'duroi),  from  french  corde  du  roi ,  ''kings  cord. a  fabric,  usually  of  cotton,  with  lengthwise  rows,  or  cords,  of  pile  on the  face.  found  in  white  or  any  plain  color.  much  used  for  suits and  trousers  for  men  and  boys,  lounging  robes  and  sports  wear  for women,  coats  and  wraps  for  children.  found  also  in  wool.  certain qualities  used  for  hangings  and  upholstery.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: an  undyed  cotton  material,  heavily  napped  on  both sides,  used  for  silence  cloths  under  tablecloths.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  cotton  imitation  of  silk  foulard.  see  foulard.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: cotton  material  of  same  weave  as  wool  gabar dine.  used  for  dresses,  skirts,  blouses,  etc.  see  gabardine.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  thin  silk  or  cotton  material  treated  on  one  side with  a  medicated  glue  which  will  adhere  to  the  skin.  found  in  white, flesh  color,  and  black.  the  beauty  patches  of  colonial  times  were  of black  court  plaster.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth,  twilled  material  of  wool,  cotton,  or  a mixture,  with  a  fine-specked  appearance  caused  by  the  twisting  to gether  of  white  and  colored  singles  to  make  the  warp  yarns.  used for  riding  habits,  suits,  coats,  and  wraps.  frequently  cravenetted  or rubberized  for  rainproof  garments.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  coarse,  rough,  plain-woven  fabric  found  in  cotton,  linen, and  union  materials.  may  be  unbleached,  partly  bleached,  white,  or dyed.  found  in  many  widths  and  qualities.  used  for  towels,  covers, and  decorative  household  articles.  at  times  fashionable  for  suits  and dresses.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (krap),  "curled.  a  general  term  applied  to  materials  hav ing  a  pebbly  effect  produced  by  twists  in  the  yarns  and  by  varying the  tension  in  weaving.  see  crepe  de  chine,  georgette  crepe,  japanese crepe,  and  serpentine  crepe.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (krap  d  shen'),  "crepe  of  china.  a  light-weight, closely  woven  silk  material,  alike  on  face  and  back.  in  white  and plain  colors.  many  weights  and  qualities,  but  almost  always  satis factory  in  wear.  found  in  cotton,  silk,  and  mixtures.  used  for blouses,  gowns,  trimmings,  lingerie.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  medium-weight  cotton  material  usually  printed  with elaborate  floral  designs.  found  in  various  qualities,  the  better  ones often  warp  printed.  used  for  pillows  and  draperies  and  for  decora tive  household  articles.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: dimity  with  a  heavy  cord  at  regular  intervals  in both  warp  and  filling.  see  dimity. damask  (from  damascus) .  a  smooth  material,  usually  of  jac quard  weave,  made  originally  of  silk,  now  made  of  linen,  cotton,  or mixtures.  found  in  many  widths  and  a  great  variety  of  designs.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  firm,  strong,  twilled  cotton  material  usually  found  in dark  blue  or  brown.  formerly  had  specked  effect  produced  by  twist ing  a  white  ply  into  the  filling  yarn.  used  for  mens  overalls  and jumpers  and  for  childrens  rompers  and  play  suits.  certain  qualities are  used  for  draperies,  couch  covers,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  strong,  yarn-dyed  cotton  material  much  used  for house  dresses,  childrens  rompers,  nurses  uniforms,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  fine,  crisp,  light-weight  cotton  material,  white  or  in plain  colors.  used  for  aprons,  dresses,  and  underwear.  see  striped dimity  and  crossbar  dimity.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: swiss,  or  muslin,  having  a  pattern of  dots  woven  in  at  regular  intervals  with  soft,  heavy  yarn.  many qualities.  used  for  aprons,  curtains,  trimmings  on  wash  dresses,  etc. see  swiss
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: any  fabric  which  is  made  by the  use  of  more  than  one  warp  or  filling  in  its  construction,  or  by  the simultaneous  weaving  and  fastening  together  of  two  or  more  cloths. examples,  bathrobe  material,  marseilles  counterpanes,  steamer  rugs. name  usually  applied  to  double  cloth  used  for  suits  and  coats
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: strong,  twilled  cotton  material.  white,  un bleached,  or  colored.  many  grades.  used  for  middy  blouses,  sum mer  trousers,  heavy  linings,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  close,  heavy  cotton  fabric  of  plain  weave.  sometimes two  yarns  used  as  one  in  the  warp.  white  or  colored.  many  widths and  weights.  heavy  grades  practically  water  tight  and  used  for  tents, awnings,  sails,  tarpaulins,  sea  kits,  etc.  lighter  weights  used  for clothing.  see  canvas,  awning  cloth,  and  sailcloth.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (doo-ve  ten'),  from  french  duvet ,  "down.  a  soft,  light weight  material  of  silk,  wool,  or  a  mixture,  with  a  downy  nap  raised by  emery  rollers.  used  for  suits,  wraps,  and  millinery.  to  a  consid erable  extent  it  replaces  velvet.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (from  the  down  of  the  eider  duck).  a  light-weight knitted  material  with  a  thick,  fluffy  nap  of  wool  on  one  or  both  sides. formerly  much  used  for  bathrobes,  baby  blankets,  etc.  now  replaced somewhat  by  bathrobe  material.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  mercerized  cotton  lining  material  of  satin  weave and  high  polish.  may  be  plain,  colored,  or  printed.  also  called
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: used  for  linings.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  wool  material  with  the  fibers  so  matted  and  pressed  to gether  as  entirely  to  obscure  the  method  of  construction.  high-grade felts  are  woven ;  common  felts  are  not  woven,  but  are  made  by shrinking  and  matting  the  fibers  together.  many  weights  and  qual ities.  used  for  billiard-table  and  card-table  covers,  pads  to  prevent scratching  of  furniture,  slippers,  pennants,  rug  linings,  etc.  see  cot ton  felt.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  soft,  light-weight  wool  material  slightly  napped  on both  face  and  back.  in  white  and  plain  colors.  used  for  middy blouses,  mens  shirts  and  sports  trousers,  dresses,  underwear,  and childrens  clothes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  light-weight  cotton  material  napped  on  the  face. may  be  white,  dyed,  or  printed.  used  for  kimonos,  sleeping  gar ments,  dressing  sacques,  and  gowns.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth,  crisp,  light-weight  cotton  material  resembling dimity.  found  plain  or  with  cords.  white,  tinted,  or  with  printed figures.  used  for  aprons,  lingerie,  infants  wear,  etc. foulard  (fob-lard1';  french,  foolaf),  "silk  handkerchief.  a  soft, firm,  light-weight  silk  material  of  plain  or  twill  weave,  usually printed.  wears  well.  used  for  kimonos,  gowns,  linings.  see  cotton foulard  and  shower-proof  foulard.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  firm,  smooth,  wool  dress  material woven  with  a  steep  twill.  many  weights  and  qualities.  used  for  suits and  gowns.  see  cotton  gabardine.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: an  almost  transparent  silk  material  found  in white  and  plain  colors ;  also  printed.  used  for  blouses,  gowns,  trim mings,  dainty  lingerie,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  firm,  smooth  cotton  material,  usually  yarn  dyed  and woven  in  checks,  plaids,  or  stripes.  sometimes  found  in  white  and plain  colors.  many  weights  and  qualities.  used  for  childrens  clothes, womens  dresses,  aprons,  nurses  uniforms,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  thin  silk  material  made  with  gauze  weave.  much used  a  few  generations  ago  for  womens  dresses.  seldom  found  now.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  thin,  firm  cotton  material  gummed  on  one  side. used  for  mending  torn  music  sheets,  book  leaves,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: material  made  with  cotton  or  linen  warp  and  horse hair  filling.  hair  filling  thrown  to  face  by  satin  weave.  formerly used  for  upholstery.  now  used  for  millinery  and  stiffening  in  coats.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  fine,  soft  linen  material  used  principally  for handkerchiefs.  found  in  white  and  plain  colors.  also  used  for  in fants  wear,  lingerie,  blouses,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  coarse,  strong  wool  material  made  of  rough  yarns glossary  of  materials 353 in  mixed  colors.  originally  hand  woven  in  the  homes  of  scotch  and
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: now  made  commercially.  similar  to  tweed.  used for  overcoats,  caps,  and  sports  suits  for  both  men  and  women.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: commonly  called  huck.  a  linen  material  originally peddled  by  hucksters  in  the  british  isles.  name  now  applied  to cotton,  linen,  or  union  materials  woven  with  the  small  figured  design found  in  all  huckaback.  used  for  towels.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  yarn-dyed  three-ply  carpeting  woven  on  a
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: pattern  reversible  on  face  and  back.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  rough  cotton  crepe,  in  white  and  plain  colors. does  not  require  ironing  when  laundered. used  for  childrens  clothes, womens  dresses,  aprons,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  general  name  given  to  plain-knitted  material  used  for garments.  may  be  of  cotton,  wool,  silk,  artificial  silk,  or  a  mixture of  fibers.  great  variety  of  weights,  qualities,  and  colors.  used  for knitted  underwear,  blouses,  gowns,  suits,  coats,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (ka'ke),  from  east  indian,  "dust-colored.  a  strong twilled  cotton  material  of  dust  color  used  for  uniforms  of  american soldiers.  many  weights  and  qualities.  made  for  civilian  purposes. used  for  boy  scout  suits,  summer  suits  for  men  and  women  for  out door  work,  camping,  fishing,  tramping,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  soft,  plain-woven,  light-weight  silk,  usually  printed in  elaborate  designs.  used  for  kimonos,  linings,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: materials  of  open  structure  made  either  by  hand  or  on  lace machines.  used  for  trimmings  and  decorative  articles.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  cotton  material  finished  to  imitate  linen.  finish  de stroyed  by  laundering.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  floor  covering  made  by  using  a  specially  prepared heavy  paint  on  a  strong  burlap  or  hemp  foundation.  many  grades.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  cotton  imitation  of  handkerchief  linen.  see  linene.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  material  never  found  now.  a  durable  but  un attractive  material  of  wool  and  flax,  hand  spun,  home  dyed,  and  hand woven  by  our  colonial  ancestors.  used  for  dresses  of  the  women and  children.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  fine,  smooth,  light-weight,  closely  woven  cotton material  with  soft  finish.  used  for  infants  clothes  and  lingerie.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: heavy  wool  coating,  usually  of  double  cloth,  yarn- dyed  and  woven  in  plaids.  used  for  coats  for  men,  women,  and  chil dren.  worn  especially  by  loggers,  trappers,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (from  madras,  name  of  a  city  in  india).  a  firm,  smooth, soft-finished  cotton  material  similar  to  a  good  quality  of  gingham. usually  yarn  dyed  and  often  contains  small  jacquard  design. used for  shirts,  pajamas,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  material  of  gauze  weave  having  a  pattern  woven  in with  soft,  heavy  yarns,  the  cut  ends  of  which  give  a  shaggy  effect  to the  back  of  the  material.  used  for  curtains  and  draperies.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: an  open  silk  or  cotton  material  of  gauze  weave  simi lar  to  grenadine.  may  be  made  of  mixed  fibers.  many  grades.  used for  dresses,  curtains,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (marsalz'),  from  marseilles,  name  of  a  city  in  france. a  cotton  double  cloth,  often  with  elaborate  floral  design,  the  pattern being  made  by  the  releasing  and  combining  of  the  different  ply  as  the cloth  is  woven.  used  for  bedspreads.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  brilliant,  metallic  material  made  with  a  cotton  warp and  filling  of  metal  novelty  yarns.  used  for  millinery,  trimmings, lamp  shades,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  material  of  bright  metal  colors  and  brilliant luster.  made  with  silk  or  cotton  warp  and  artificial  silk  filling.  an imitation  of  metal  cloth  and  used  for  the  same  purposes. milanese  (from  milan,  name  of  a  city  in  italy).  a  silk  underwear material  knitted  on  a  warp-knitting  frame.  does  not  ravel.  used  for underwear,  gloves,  hosiery,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (mo'ra ;  french,  mwara'),  "watered  silk.  a  silk  material (usually  poplin)  with  a  watered  effect  on  the  face.  finish  produced by  heat,  moisture,  and  etched  rollers.  used  for  millinery,  wraps, gowns,  trimmings,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  coarse,  rough  cotton  material  with  conspicuous basket  weave.  usually  dust-colored  but  may  be  dyed.  used  for draperies,  couch  covers,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: an  artificial  (rayon)  horsehair.  used  in  millinery,  braids, etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  cotton  or  linen  toweling  of  irregular  weave  giv ing  a  pebbly  effect.  used  for  towels,  runners,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  general  term  for  plain  white  or  unbleached  cotton  mate rials  used  for  underwear  and  household  purposes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  fine,  smooth,  soft  cotton  material,  usually  white  but may  be  tinted.  many  grades.  used  for  infants  wear  and  lingerie.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  mercerized  cotton  lining  material.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: an  openwork  material  usually  made  on  the  lace machine.  forms  the  foundation  for  a  great  variety  of  laces.  used for  curtains,  millinery,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: an  olive  drab  flannel  made  to  exact  specifications  by the  united  states  government  for  the  uniforms  of  our  soldiers.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  material  painted  on  one  side  with  a  specially  prepared paint.  lighter  weights  used  for  kitchen  aprons,  table  and  shelf  cover ings,  etc.  coarser  and  heavier  grades  used  for  floor  coverings.  see linoleum.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  light-weight  silk  material  treated  with  a  special  prep aration  to  make  it  waterproof.  used  for  waterproof  garments  and toilet  purposes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth,  stiff  cotton  material  so  thin  and sheer  as  to  be  almost  transparent.  in  high-grade  qualities  the  finish is  permanent.  in  cheaper  grades  the  finish  is  destroyed  by  launder ing.  used  for  dresses,  trimmings,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  soft  cotton  material  napped  on  both  sides.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: many  qualities.  used  for  sleeping  garments, diapers,  and  infants  wear.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: one  of  the  varieties  of  mohair  materials.  at times  popular  for  mens  summer  suits.  see  alpaca.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth,  wiry  wool  material  of  plain  weave.  used  for skirts,  dresses,  suits,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  strong  silk  manufactured  especially  for  aircraft use.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: canvas  or  duck  treated  with  a  paraffin  preparation. stiff,  heavy,  and  waterproof.  used  for  coats  and  trousers  by  loggers, lumbermen,  hunters,  fishermen,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth,  closely  woven  cotton  material,  usually  printed. has  replaced  high-grade  calico  or  print. used  for  house  dresses, aprons,  and  childrens  wear.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  light-weight,  much-sized  cotton  material  with  high polish  on  face.  white  and  plain  colors.  used  for  linings. 356 how  to  know  textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  general  term  for  all  materials  having  a  raised  sur face  of  loops  or  cut  ends  on  one  or  both  sides.  examples:  bath towels,  velvet,  textile  furs.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  thin,  stiff,  almost  transparent  material with  a  high  luster.  white  or  plain  colors.  made  in  the  philippine islands  from  pineapple  fiber. used  for  curtains  and  decorative  house hold  purposes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: (pli  sa' ;  plesa'),  "pleated/  a  soft,  fine  cotton  material with  irregular  puckered  spots  over  the  surface.  permanent  effect  pro duced  by  mercerization.  does  not  require  ironing.  white,  printed, or  in  plain  colors.  used  for  underwear  and  childrens  clothes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  fabric  having  a  long,  straight  pile  on  one  side.  made  of silk,  wool,  cotton,  or  a  mixture.  used  for  millinery  and  trimmings. plush  made  of  mohair  is  used  especially  for  upholstery  in  boats,  cars, automobiles,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  strong,  rough,  dull  silk  material,  usually  tan-colored. most  frequently  made  from  wild  silk,  which  does  not  readily  bleach or  dye.  there  are  many  grades,  some  called  shantung,  rajah,  tus- sah.  also  made  of  mercerized  cotton  and  mixtures.  used  for  blouses, shirts,  pajamas,  suits,  dresses.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  corded  material  made  with  fine  warp  and  coarse  filling. may  be  of  silk,  cotton,  wool,  and  mixtures.  many  grades.  used  for suits,  dresses,  trimmings,  hangings.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  strong  material  usually  made  of  cotton  or  linen  and the  beardlike  camels  hair.  used  for  filtering.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  general  term  for  calico  and  other  low-grade  printed  cot ton  materials.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  sports  silk  similar  to  baronette  satin.  see baronette  satin
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  name  officially  recognized  by  the  federal  trade  com mission  as  the  generic  name  for  all  synthetic  fibers  made  from  cellu lose.  first  called  artificial  silk.  see  artificial  silk.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  heavy  ribbed  material  made  with  fine  warp  and  heavy filling.  ribs  larger  than  in  poplin.  found  in  silk,  cotton,  wool,  and mixtures.  many  weights.  light  weights  used  for  dresses,  suits,  and wraps  ;  heavy,  for  draperies  and  upholstery.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  trade  name  of  a  certain  firm  for  its  rayon  products made  by  the  cellulose-acetate  process.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth,  high-lustered  cotton  fabric  in  satin  weave. white,  dyed,  and  printed.  used  for  slips,  bloomers,  linings,  and comforters.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth  silk  material,  made  in  satin  weave,  having  high luster.  many  grades,  weights,  and  variations  in  weave.  may  have cotton  or  wool  back.  many  trade  names  given  to  different  varieties. see  charmeuse  and  baronette  satin
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  damask  in  plain  satin  weave.  see  damask.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  coarse  cotton  material  with  open  weave.  many  grades. used  for  curtains.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  lining  material  made  of  cotton  and  spun  silk.  similar to  a  b  c  silk.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  firm,  strong  wool  material  made  with  the  standard  2-2 twill  weave.  may  be  coarse,  harsh,  and  wiry,  as  some  storm  serges, or  fine  and  soft,  as  certain  high-grade  dress  serges.  many  grades  and weights.  also  found  in  silk,  cotton,  and  cotton-and-wool  mixtures. a  fabric  of  universal  use,  always  to  be  found.  used  for  suits  and coats  for  men  and  women,  caps,  skirts,  dresses,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  cotton  crepe  with  irregular  lengthwise  lines and  ridges  produced  by  mercerization  and  calendering.  usually printed  in  gay  and  elaborate  designs.  used  for  dressing  sacques, kimonos,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  firm,  plain-woven  cotton  (or  linen)  material.  varies in  width  from  36"  to  108".  used  for  sheets  and  pillowcases.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  two-toned  silk  material  made  with  warp  of  one  color and  filling  of  another.  called  two-toned  silk,  glace  silk,  changeable silk.  used  for  millinery,  trimmings,  gowns,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: foulard  with  a  special  finish  to  prevent water  spots.  see  foulard.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  thin  cotton  material,  dyed  or  printed,  with  a  high  pol ish  on  the  face.  polish  does  not  endure  laundering.  used  for  com forters  and  decorative  household  purposes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: an  artificial  (rayon)  wool.  used  in  wool  mixtures. soisette  (swa  set').  a  fine,  smooth,  plain,  highly  mercerized  cot ton  material.  white  or  dyed.  used  for  shirts,  pajamas,  linings, dresses,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  general  name  for  strong,  heavy  silks  with  a  some what  conspicuous  weave,  color,  or  finish.  most  commonly  made  with artificial  silk.  used  for  sports  skirts,  suits,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  two-toned  mercerized  cotton  material  used  for curtains.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  light-weight,  rubberized  cotton  fabric  used  for infants  pants,  crib  sheets,  and  toilet  purposes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: dimity  having  a  heavy  cord  at  regular  intervals in  the  warp.  see  dimity.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  crisp,  sheer  cotton  material  of  plain  weave.  plain  or having  woven  dots  or  figures.  see  dotted  swiss.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  plain,  closely  woven  silk  material,  alike  on  face  and back,  usually  finished  so  as  to  be  crisp  or  stiff.  many  grades.  also found  in  cotton.  used  for  dresses,  suits,  and  millinery. tapa,  or  tappa,  cloth.  a  fabric  of  ancient  origin  made  by  hammer ing  into  a  sheet  the  inner  bark  of  a  tree.  probably  made  by  the natives  of  the  south  sea  islands  long  before  weaving  was  invented.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  thick,  closely  woven  yarn-dyed  material  made  on  the
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: originally  hand  woven,  each  color  in  the  design being  woven  with  a  separate  bobbin.  found  in  wool,  cotton,  silk,  and mixtures.  used  for  draperies  and  upholstery.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  lower  grade  of  brussels  carpeting  with printed  instead  of  yarn-dyed  pattern.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  thin,  plain,  highly  sized  cotton  material  of  open  weave. used  for  millinery,  fancy  dress  costumes,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  cotton  or  linen  material  with  a  looped  pile  on  one or  both  sides.  heavier  weights  called  turkish  toweling  and  used  for towels,  bathrobes,  slippers,  etc.  lighter  weights  dyed  or  printed  on both  sides  and  used  for  draperies. glossary  of  materials 359
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  beautiful  light-weight  velvet  with  silk  foundation  and  rayon  pile.  see  velvet. tricolette  (tri  co  let').  a  plain-knitted  material,  usually  in  tubular form,  of  artificial  silk.  white  or  in  plain  colors.  used  for  blouses and  gowns. tricotine  (tri  co  ten').  a  firm,  soft,  smooth  wool  material  with fine  double  diagonal  lines  on  face.  effect  produced  by  special  modifi cation  of  twill  weave.  used  for  suits  and  dresses.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  plain,  unsized  cotton  material  of  a  brilliant  red color,  practically  fast.  originally  colored  with  vegetable  dyes  from
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: used  for  cushions,  trimmings,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: special  widths  of  terry  cloth  used  for  towels. see  terry  cloth
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: silk  or  a  mixture  of  silk  and  cotton  or  silk  and linen  treated  so  as  to  be  waterproof.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  general  term  for  a  large  variety  of  materials  with  pile or  heavy  nap  on  the  face.  wool  velour  is  a  soft,  warm  material  used for  dresses  and  coats.  silk  and  cotton  velours  resemble  velvet.  used for  trimmings,  millinery,  draperies,  cushions,  and  upholstery.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  lustrous  material  of  silk  or  cotton  and  silk,  with  short pile  on  the  face.  many  grades.  used  for  millinery,  suits,  dresses, trimmings,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  cotton  pile  fabric  made  in  imitation  of  velvet.  many grades.  used  for  same  purposes  as  velvet.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  soft,  warm,  wool  material,  originally  made  of  wool  from the  vicuna.  now  made  from  any  fine,  soft  wool.  used  for  coats, blankets,  robes,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: an  artificial  (rayon)  straw.  made  into  fancy  braids  and used  in  millinery.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  fine,  light-weight  flannel  made  of  wool  and  cot ton,  the  two  fibers  being  mixed  in  the  yarn.  launders  easily  and shrinks  little.  used  for  shirts,  blouses,  sports  wear,  infants  wear. 360 how  to  know  textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  smooth,  firm,  somewhat  open  material  of  plain  weave, made  with  hard-twisted  yarns.  found  in  silk,  cotton,  wool.  many grades.  white,  dyed,  or  printed.  used  for  gowns,  curtains,  trim mings,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  soft  silk  with  little  or  no  weighting  or  face  finish. yarn-dyed  or  piece-dyed  in  delicate  colors. endures  laundering.  also called  tub  silk,  shirting  silk.  used  for  shirts,  blouses,  and  lingerie.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  strong,  closely  woven,  narrow  cotton  material  much used  during  the  world  war  to  replace  leather  belts  and  straps.  also found  in  silk,  linen,  and  mixtures.  used  for  suspenders,  garters,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  firm,  smooth  material  of  wool,  cotton,  or  a  mixture, with  conspicuous  diagonal  cords  across  the  face.  used  for  suits  and coats.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: carpeting  with  deep  cut  pile  on  both  sides.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  trade  name  for  the  thick,  fleecy  nap  on  a  certain  kind of  cotton  blanket.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: general  term  for  soft  wool  materials.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: general  term  for  firm,  smooth  wool  materials.  gen erally  made  of  hard-twisted  worsted  yarns. glossary  of  terms
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  long,  strong  fibers  lying  directly  under  the  outer bark  of  various  plants,  as  flax,  hemp,  jute,  ramie,  etc.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  process,  invented  by  the  javanese,  of  resist  coloring  with the  use  of  melted  wax.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: beating  the  filling  yarns  close  together  in  weaving.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  process  of  hammering  the  surface  of  cloth  (particu larly  damasks)  so  as  to  flatten  the  yarns,  thereby  increasing  the luster.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  process  of  extracting  the  natural  coloring  matter from  materials,  leaving  them  white.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  running  of  colors  in  dyed  materials.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  mixing  of  different  kinds  or  colors  of  fibers  to  produce a  desired  yarn.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  stamping  of  color  on  cloth  by  hand  with carved  wooden  blocks.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: silk  from  which  the  gum  has  been  removed.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  crushing  of  the  straw  of  flax  (hemp,  jute,  ramie, etc.)  to  loosen  the  bast  fiber  from  the  outer  bark  and  woody  tissue of  the  plant.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  term  applied  to  dress  silks  and  linings  of  common width,  to  distinguish  them  from  wide  ribbons  and  silks  of  very  nar row  widths.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  removal  of  knots,  burrs,  etc.  from  the  surface  of cloth  during  the  finishing  process.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  process  of  removing  a  textile  material  by means  of  a  chemical  which  destroys  or  burns  out  the  fabric.  used particularly  with  imitation  venise  lace.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  term  used  for  pressing  cloth  with  heavy  rollers during  the  finishing  process,  to  give  it  the  desired  polish.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  removal  of  foreign  substances  from  fibers  or cloth  by  burning  out  with  chemicals.  the  process  is  used  particularly for  destroying  vegetable  matter  in  wool  or  wool  materials. 361 362 how  to  know  textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: untangling  and  straightening  out  textile  fibers.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  chemical  solution  into  which  certain  kinds  of fiber  or  cloth  are  submerged  during  the  manufacturing  process,  to produce  permanent  changes.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: cutting  the  long  fibers  on  the  surface  of  cloth  to  make them  of  equal  length.  process  used  particularly  with  broadcloths  and pile  fabrics. cloth  glass,  or  cloth  tester.  see  weavers  glass.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  process  following  carding  to  still  further  straighten out  the  fibers  and  lay  them  parallel.  used  particularly  with  wool for  worsteds  and  with  long-stapled  cotton  for  fine  goods.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: spots  of  colored  or  white  paste  deposited  on the  face  of  cloth  to  make  the  pattern.  more  effective  for  certain materials  than  printing.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  number  of  warp  and  filling  yarns  in  a  square inch  of  material.  the  weight  and  fineness  of  cloth  can  be  judged  by the  count.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  fineness  to  which  it  is  spun.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  horizontal  ridges  in  knitted  materials  made  by  the tops  of  the  stitches  as  they  have  been  thrown  off  by  the  needles  in  the knitting  process.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: treating  fibers  or  fabrics  with  a  chemical  substance to  make  them  moisture  resistant.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  rubbing  off  of  color  from  a  dyed  material.  cheap colored  hosiery  and  linings  sometimes  crock.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: bleaching  on  the  grass.  a  term  used  particularly  in  the british  isles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  dyeing  of  a  material  containing  both  animal and  vegetable  fibers  with  a  dye  which  colors  only  one  kind  of  fiber. wool  and  cotton  mixtures  are  often  cross  dyed
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: an  old  expression  for  "bolt  of  cloth,  or  the  lengths into  which  the  entire  woven  piece  is  cut.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  cleaning  of  the  bark  and  woody  tissue  from the  fiber  of  the  plant.  term  used  especially  in  the  manufacture  of ramie  and  hemp.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  french  unit  of  weight  of  about  5  centigrams.  used  in determining  the  size,  or  "count,  of  silk  and  rayon  yarns.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  stamping  of  color  on  the  surface  of  the material.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  printing  of  a  pattern  with  chemicals  on  the surface  of  a  dyed  fabric.  when  the  cloth  is  submitted  to  the  proper after  treatments,  the  color  will  be  removed,  or  discharged,  from  these printed  spots.  white  patterns  on  dyed  cotton  materials  are  fre quently  obtained  by  the  discharge  process.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  instrument  in  a  printing  machine  which  re moves  all  extraneous  coloring  substance  from  the  carved  roller  which is  to  stamp  the  pattern  on  the  cloth.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  process,  in  the  manufacture  of  yarn,  in  which  many slivers  are  drawn  into  one.  the  more  times  this  doubling  process  is performed,  the  more  thoroughly  the  fibers  are  mixed  and  blended.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  soft,  fine  undergrowth  of  hair.  certain  animals,  as goats  and  camels,  produce  both  coarse  beard  hair  and  fine  down  hair.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: pulling  out,  or  attenuating,  the  big,  soft  rope  of  fibers, as  it  leaves  the  card  or  comb,  into  the  desired  size  of  yarn.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  cleaned  flax  fiber  that  is  ready  to  be  spun  into yarn.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  substance  used  in  the  finishing  of  cloth  to  give  it the  proper  weight,  stiffness,  or  polish.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  printing  of  a  pattern  on  both  the  face  and the  back  of  a  fabric.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  printing  of  both  the  face  and  the  back  of a  fabric  with  the  pattern  as  accurately  placed  as  if  the  design  had been  stamped  through.  duplicate  printed  materials  can  easily  be  mis taken  for  warp-dyed  goods.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  coloring  of  a  material  by  immersion  in  a  color  bath. see  cross  dyeing,  stock  dyeing,  and  tie  dyeing.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: increasing  the  weight  of  silk  by  dipping  it  into  a mineral  solution.  the  process  is  also  called  weighting  or  loading.  a small  amount  of  loading  is  not  injurious  to  the  fiber.  a  large  amount greatly  weakens  it.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: raising  nap  on  the  surface  of  goods  by  emery-covered rollers.  chamoisette  for  gloves,  duvetyn  and  materials  with  a  "peach bloom    surface  are  emerized.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  mill  term  for  warp  yams.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  right  side  as  distinguished  from  the  wrong.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  mill  and  trade  term  to  describe  the  character  of cloth  as  determined  by  handling.  the  expression  "leathery  feel  is used  especially  with  table  linens.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: machines  for  reeling  silk  mechanically.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  common  name  for  the  yarns  carried  by  the  shuttle across  the  warp  in  weaving.  old  terms  for  these  yarns  are  woof  and weft.  the  mill  term  is  picks.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  powder,  starch,  or  clay  used  in  the  finishing  process to  increase  the  weight  or  fill  the  interstices  in  coarse  or  loosely  woven cloth.  cheap  cottons,  linens,  and  pongees  often  contain  much  filling.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  term  used  in  dyeing  or  printing  when  the  colors  are  made permanent  or  fast.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  machine  or  implement  used  for  breaking  the  flax straw  so  that  the  woody  substance  can  be  cleaned  from  the  fiber. breaking  is  the  first  process  in  flax  preparation  after  retting
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  long  yarn,  either  warp  or  filling,  exposed  on  the  sur face  of  cloth  in  weaving.  these  floats  give  smoothness  to  satins, sateens,  plain  damasks,  etc.  and  beauty  to  pattern  weaving.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  short  fiber  ends  that  are  clipped  off  the  surface  of wool  materials  and  napped  goods  in  the  finishing  process.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  term  used  in  the  manufacture  of  wool  materials  when they  are  reduced  in  width  and  length.  other  terms  for  the  same process  are  shrunk,  milled,  felted.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: term  used  of  knitted  underwear  and  hosiery.  in full-fashioned  garments  flat,  shaped  pieces  are  knitted  and  then  sewed together  to  form  a  permanently  shaped  garment.  circular  knitted garments  are  knitted  in  tubular  form  and  then  shaped  by  pressing.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  tearing  of  manufactured  materials  into  fibers. one  of  the  first  processes  in  securing  wool  for  remanufacture
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  removal  of  the  short  fiber  ends  on  the  surface  of  yarn or  cloth  by  burning.  used  particularly  with  cottons.  another  term for  the  same  process  is  singeing.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: one  of  the  early  processes  in  the  cleaning  of  flax.  after the  breaking  process  the  flax  is  drawn  by  hand  or  machine  over combs  which  rake  out  the  woody  tissue  and  separate  the  flax  fibers.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  part  of  a  loom  which  controls  the  lifting  of  the warp  yarns.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: one  of  the  cords  or  wires  of  which  the  harness  is  made. each  heald  carries  one  warp  yarn. sometimes  called  heddles.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  tool  with  long  teeth  through  which  flax  is  drawn  when dressed  by  hand.  also  called  hatchel  and  hackle.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  mill  expression  for  the  woven  cloth  before  it  has been  bleached  or  colored.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: when  flax  fiber  is  partly  cleaned  but  still  tangled and  dirty,  it  is  spoken  of  as  in  the  rough.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  coarse,  dead  wool  fibers  in  a  fleece.  these  do  not manufacture  well.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  mill  term  for  a  wide  sheet  of  fibers  before  it  is  drawn  out into  slivers.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  eye  in  the  center  of  the  heald,  through  which  the warp  yarn  is  drawn.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  long,  straight  fibers  of  dressed  flax  which  have  been separated  from  the  broken,  tangled  ones  in  the  cleaning  process. linen  glass,  or  linen  tester.  see  weavers  glass.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: cotton  fiber  after  ginning.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: cotton  seeds  to  which  considerable  fiber  still  clings  after the  ginning  process.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: ironing  cloth  or  garments  between  rollers.  a  laundry term.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  chemical  process  used  with  cotton.  mercerizing straightens  and  plumps  the  cotton  fiber,  causing  it  to  be  more  lustrous and  take  dye  better.  mercerizing  correctly  done  strengthens  the cotton  fiber.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  general  term  for  the  by-products  of  various  mill operations.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  chemical  used  with  some  kinds  of  dyes  to  increase their  affinity  for  the  fibers.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: term  applied  to  the  lowest  class  of  remanufactured  wool.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: pulling  the  ends  of  the  fibers  to  the  surface  of  the  cloth to  form  a  fuzz  or  pile.  when  done  with  teazels  the  process  is  called teazling.  broadcloth  and  outing  flannel  are  examples  of  napped goods.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  broken  and  tangled  fibers  left  when  wool  is  combed  for making  worsteds,  or  silk  for  making  spun  silk.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  kind  of  novelty  yarn.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  fine,  strong  silk  yarn  used  for  warp.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  machine  for  cutting  the  pattern  on  the  copper rollers  used  in  printing.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  mill  term  for  one  of  the  inspections  of  cloth  during its  manufacture.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: one  of  the  filling  yarns  in  cloth.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  work  of  the  shuttle  as  it  carries  the  filling  yarn through  the  warp  yarns  in  weaving.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: one  of  the  several  yarns  which  are  twisted  together  to  form a  coarser  yarn  or  sewing  thread.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  term  used  with  dyed  silks  to  show  that  there  has  been little  or  no  weighting  used.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: textile  fibers  which  have  not  been  through  any manufacturing  process.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: wool  fiber  taken,  or  reclaimed,  from  manufac tured  materials.  commonly  called  shoddy.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: winding  off  the  fiber  from  silk  cocoons.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  method  of  dyeing  whereby  certain  parts  of  the material  are  covered  with  a  wax  or  paste  which  is  resistant  to  the  dye. this  process  is  used  in  batik  printing  and,  to  a  certain  extent,  in  com mercial  printing.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  decomposition,  or  rotting,  of  the  woody  tissues  in bast  fibers.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: the  removal  of  the  leaves,  seeds,  and  roots  from  the flax  plant.  the  first  process  in  the  preparation  of  flax  for  manu facture.
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Title: How to Know Textiles
